node.title: 'I really took a lot of things for granted': How an accident made Jacob realise the problem with festivals
node.alt: Jacob in wheelchair on platform in front of festival crowds
node.description: In 2019, Jacob broke his neck by doing a front flip. The incident crushed his spinal cord and he spent the next nine months in hospital. It wasn't long after leaving the hospital that Jacob started looking into attending gigs again, only to realise just how difficult accessing the venues were.
node.content:
["Before he could crawl Jacob Cremen-Darkin\u00a0had already gotten his hands on his father's guitar. For him, music is a universal language. His favourite memory is when he got to play a baby grand piano during year 8 for the graduating class.", "\"I guess before I really took a lot of things for granted,\" he said.", "In 2019, the Parramatta man broke his neck doing a front flip. Ending up on his head, Mr Cremen-Darkin's crushed his spinal cord and spent the next nine months in hospital.", "But it wasn't long before he started looking into attending gigs again, only then realising how difficult it would be.", "\"Just being able to rock up, not worry about the accessibility, having a spot where I could see the actual show, not having to think about the bathrooms because I could go anywhere \u2026 I wouldn't have to think about that.\"", "Jacob isn't alone: 4.4 million Australians live with some form of disability\u2014\u00a0that's 17.7 per cent of the population. But having a disability doesn't mean one can't enjoy music.", "\"We all love music. We all like to celebrate it,\" he says.", "People living with disabilities around the country report issues\u00a0with accessible seating sections,\u00a0segregation\u00a0from regular concert goers, or having\u00a0something block\u00a0their direct line of sight.", "Likewise, many report difficulty with\u00a0participating in VIP experiences, and are often deterred from purchasing them due to inaccessibility.", "Self-employed Penrith woman Pauline David\u00a0has spina bifida and regularly attends events.", "Most of the time Ms David says she'll pay for a seat in the gold section, but the ticketing company will assign her to a non-wheelchair accessible seat.", "\"I've gotten to the venue, but there's no wheelchair spot because they give you tickets for spots that have a seat\u2026they've got to relocate you, and sometimes they'll relocate you to a spot that's [worth] less monetary value,\" Ms David says.", "\"They'll relocate me to the silver or bronze areas, but I don't get the [refund] back.\"", "", "
Jimmy Barnes
", "
'The nosebleed section'
", "Rock legend Jimmy Barnes says the issue of inaccessibility doesn't just affect disabled fans, but artists living with disability as well. He says he's lucky to have his daughter Elly-May, who has cerebral palsy, on tour with him frequently.", "\"We have found that most venues have not had enough thought put into accessibility\u2026With a lot of help from our road crews and production people, we have been able to make things a little easier for Elly-May to get around. But even with all that help it is still difficult.\"", "Having seen firsthand the lack of access backstage while performing, the Working Class Man singer says he would love to see \"a lot more consideration for all\" when it comes to constructing the back and front of performance venues, specifically with \"stairs and sight lines.\"", "\"I know that stepping out from backstage opens Elly-May up to whole lot of different issues including. I often see a disabled section of a venue somewhere up the back in the nosebleed section of a room. Disabled fans pay the same money and are entitled to the same benefits as anyone else\u2026The experience is not the same when the band you are seeing is so far away they look like ants.\"", "", "
Ms Greenwood lives with Ehlers Danlos Syndrome, a degenerative genetic condition that affects the joints.(\u00a0Supplied: Xena Greenwood)
", "
Artistry for all
", "When Xena Greenwood\u00a0moved to regional Victoria, her enjoyment of the arts was diminished due to being unable to access many venues.", "Ms Greenwood lives with Ehlers Danlos Syndrome, a degenerative genetic condition that affects the joints. Due to her disability, Ms Greenwood often uses mobility aids.", "One of her local arts venues has two theatres, with the one most in use situated up a flight of stairs.", "\"I'm supposed to call ahead of time, so that they can push [the wheelchair lift] there\u2026But I'm a rollator user, and I'm not allowed to use the wheelchair lift,\" she says.", "There have been several times where Ms Greenwood hasn't even been able to enter a building, or she's had to pay triple the amount for tickets to shows as the only accessible seating area exists in the top tier ticket allocation.", "When Ms Greenwood has brought up these issues, she's been called \"whiny\" and \"entitled\".", "\"[Older generations] did not grow up with people like us, did not see us in the community and they're just not making that mental shift.\"", "
Focus on ability
", "Currently working on a tech start-up company to connect young adults to the right mental health professional, Mr Cremen-Darkin knows the value of finding the right person to help.", "With the help of Hireup, Mr Cremen-Darkin was able to find a carer and attend Ability Fest, Australia's first and only fully inclusive music festival.", "\"When I rocked up to the entrance, they had one laid out pathway on the grass with this special plastic mat. It was just nice to know they [people with disability] were the majority for a change. And they got to be treated like they were important. That was really nice to see.", "Andrew Thomas, a representative from Hireup, says there are many ways festivals and events can become more inclusive for everyone.", "\"Having viewing platforms so that festival goers are part of the event and not tucked off to the side, accessible toilets, quiet zones, pathways if the event is held on uneven surface and to create a way to negotiate crowds, reduce strobe light usage, have an Auslan interpreter.\"", "", "
Auslan interpreter Susan Emerson learnt full sets of songs to translate for the crowd.(ABC News: Nicole Asher)
", "Mr Thomas says these are just some of the simple and effective actions that festival organisers can take to make their event more accessible.", "\"It really opened my eyes up to what we can do better,\" Mr Cremen-Darkin says.", "
Attitude is everything
", "One country that is ahead of Australia\u00a0with\u00a0an impressive program for festival goers of all abilities is the United Kingdom.", "Attitude is Everything are a disability-led charity working in partnership with the disabled community and the industry to make festivals more accessible and inclusive.", "Suzanne Bull is the founder of Attitude is Everything, and says the changes made by organisation wouldn't have been possible without its volunteers.", "\"We asked disabled people to volunteer, acting as our 'mystery shoppers' who attend venues and festivals and collect feedback on their experiences as customers at events\u2026This is given to promoters and managers in a structured way so that they are able to make improvements.\"", "This tactic also provides evidence to policymakers and trade bodies about barriers and the solutions for improving access at major festivals and the camping grounds.", "Ms Bull says they've received positive support from the disabled community who trust Attitude is Everything to represent them in the appropriate way, and to resolve matters on their behalf.", "\"Equally we have trust and respect from the music and live events industries who know that we're there to support them to offer support and guidance. To be valued by both the disabled community and the industry sectors is important and not something that achievable by every organisation,\" she says.", "In 2014, Attitude is Everything were commissioned by the Equal Opportunities Council and the Norwegian Live Music Association to develop a franchise model of their Charter of Best Practice for Norway.", "\"We spoke at industry events about the project, delivered training, conducted site-visits\u2026and worked with disabled people in Norway to develop a model.\"", "The experience put them in a strong position to engage with other countries who wish to implement the highly successful model. Recently, the charity has begun to work with various arts organisations across Australia.", "", "
The festival at Marion Bay has been a way for music lovers in Tasmania to mark New Year's each year.\u00a0(ABC: triple j/Damien Peck)
", "Ms Bull says they are supporting a project mapping the access provision of venues and their websites in Sydney. She hopes this will push out to Victoria as well.", "They are also in touch with Arts Access Australia as they examine options for a national scheme to promote arts accessibility.", "
On the Horizon
", "With COVID19 changing the way festivals are run, perhaps organisers will be more inclined to work with the disabled community to find a solution which benefits everyone involved.", "\"I think [festival organisers] need to have someone with a disability or lived experience\u2026 sitting on board, decision makers or events\u2026We shouldn't discriminate. [We] shouldn't be an afterthought,\" Mr Cremen-Darkin says.", "\"I think people are only just starting to realise that disabled people have the right to\u2026accessibility to the arts and cultural events\u2026It's been very frustrating because the arts, music, theatre, all of that really does broaden your horizon,\" Ms Greenwood says."]
